us.ihmc.euclid.geometry

Class Orientation2D

  • java.lang.Object
    • us.ihmc.euclid.geometry.Orientation2D
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Orientation2DBasics, Orientation2DReadOnly, us.ihmc.euclid.interfaces.Clearable, us.ihmc.euclid.interfaces.EpsilonComparable<Orientation2D>, us.ihmc.euclid.interfaces.GeometricallyComparable<Orientation2D>, us.ihmc.euclid.interfaces.GeometryObject<Orientation2D>, us.ihmc.euclid.interfaces.Settable<Orientation2D>, us.ihmc.euclid.interfaces.Transformable

    public class Orientation2D
extends java.lang.Object
implements Orientation2DBasics, us.ihmc.euclid.interfaces.GeometryObject<Orientation2D>
    A Orientation2D represents an orientation in the XY-plane, i.e. the yaw angle about the z-axis.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Orientation2D()
      Creates a new orientation 2D initialized with its yaw angle to zero.

      Creates a new orientation 2D and initializes its yaw angle to the given yaw.
      Orientation2D(Orientation2DReadOnly other)
      Creates a new orientation 2D and initializes it to other.

      • setYaw

        public void setYaw(double yaw)
        Sets the yaw angle of this orientation 2D.

        Note that the argument is trimmed to be contained in [-pi, pi].

        Specified by:
        setYaw in interface Orientation2DBasics
        Parameters:
        yaw - the new yaw angle value in radians.

      • getYaw

        public double getYaw()
        Returns the current yaw angle of this orientation 2D.
        Specified by:

        Returns:
        the angle value in radians.

      • applyTransform

        public void applyTransform(us.ihmc.euclid.transform.interfaces.Transform transform)
        Transforms this orientation 2D by the given transform.

        This is equivalent to extracting the yaw rotation part from the given transform and adding it to this.

        Specified by:
        applyTransform in interface Orientation2DBasics
        Specified by:
        applyTransform in interface us.ihmc.euclid.interfaces.Transformable
        Parameters:
        transform - the geometric transform to apply on this orientation 2D. Not modified.

      • applyInverseTransform

        public void applyInverseTransform(us.ihmc.euclid.transform.interfaces.Transform transform)
        Transforms this orientation 2D by the inverse of the given transform.

        This is equivalent to extracting the yaw rotation part from the given transform and subtracting it to this.

        Specified by:
        applyInverseTransform in interface Orientation2DBasics
        Specified by:
        applyInverseTransform in interface us.ihmc.euclid.interfaces.Transformable
        Parameters:
        transform - the geometric transform to apply on this orientation 2D. Not modified.

      • epsilonEquals

        public boolean epsilonEquals(Orientation2D other,
                             double epsilon)
        Tests if the yaw angle of this orientation is equal to an epsilon to the yaw of other.

        Note that this method performs number comparison and not an angle comparison, such that: -pi ≠ pi.

        Specified by:
        epsilonEquals in interface us.ihmc.euclid.interfaces.EpsilonComparable<Orientation2D>
        Parameters:
        other - the query. Not modified.
        epsilon - the tolerance to use.
        Returns:
        true if the two orientations are equal, false otherwise.

      • geometricallyEquals

        public boolean geometricallyEquals(Orientation2D other,
                                   double epsilon)
        Compares this to other to determine if the two orientations are geometrically similar, i.e. the difference in yaw of this and other is less than or equal to epsilon.
        Specified by:
        geometricallyEquals in interface us.ihmc.euclid.interfaces.GeometricallyComparable<Orientation2D>
        Parameters:
        other - the orientation to compare to. Not modified.
        epsilon - the tolerance of the comparison.
        Returns:
        true if the two orientations represent the same geometry, false otherwise.
